CBET-1449247 
Mladenov 

RAPID: Toward an improved understanding of reactive organic carbon sources and arsenic mobility in reducing aquifers 

Arsenic is a world-wide issue in groundwater when used as a source of drinking water. A study in 2007 suggests that over 137 million people in more than 70 countries, including the United States, are affected by this poison. A challenge is to better understand the chemistry of arsenic in groundwater in order to inform engineering decisions in treating that water to make is safe for drinking. One of the important considerations is the presence of dissolved organic matter, often referred to as DOM. There is some controversy over the source of this DOM, as to whether it is the result of the discharge of wastewater or is from natural sources. Both are possible; however it appears that in most cases it is naturally occurring organic matter that is present in the ground waters. In turn, this DOM can react naturally with microorganisms, which in turn can affect the chemistry of the arsenic. The challenge of identifying the sources of reactive organic carbon (DOM) driving microbial reduction continues to limit our ability to predict the distribution of arsenic in reducing aquifers. 

The proposed research is a concerted effort to correlate analytical methods for dissolved organic matter (DOM) characterization and reactivity to fluorescence spectral acquisition of DOM collected from uncompromised sediment pore-water. This will provide new information about the potential and limits of fluorescence spectroscopy for characterizing DOM in reducing environments that often have high metal content. In addition, via this coordinated drilling effort at sites with and without large-scale pumping, DOM chemical characterization and large volume sampling for radiocarbon dating will test the hypothesis that, in the absence of massive irrigation pumping, sediments may provide labile DOM to drive microbial reductive dissolution of arsenic. Samples will be collected and analyzed to provide key information regarding DOM source and age under scenarios that are generalizable to other aquifers. With the unique freeze-shoe sampling technology and availability of a mobile laboratory, this effort will allow for the optimization of techniques appropriate for large volume sampling, uncompromised pore-water sampling, and rapid DOM characterization. The proposed research takes advantage of multiple datasets being collected by scientists and students from 16 different countries in the summer of 2014. The drilling effort utilizes novel freeze-shoe sampling technology to collect uncompromised sediments and adjacent pore-waters from the arsenic-containing Mahomet Aquifer (Illinois) for immediate analysis at a mobile laboratory at the site. The proposed RAPID project will support sample collection at the Mahomet Aquifer field site and preparation of samples for radiocarbon dating and determinations of proteins, carbohydrates, and fulvic acids. The next large sampling similar to this will not be for three years.

por.por_cntn:
Arsenic is one of the most infamous toxic trace elements responsible for the contamination of groundwater aquifers used for drinking water supply. Worldwide, there are more 100 million people, including many in the United States, affected by arsenic-contaminated groundwater (Figure 1). A challenge is to better understand the biological and chemical reactions of arsenic in groundwater in order to inform engineering decisions that address the arsenic contamination problem. One of the important considerations that affect both remediation of aquifers and treatment of arsenic-contaminated water is the presence of dissolved organic matter, referred to as DOM. In reducing aquifers, DOM has a central influence on high arsenic concentrations in groundwater. It is known that DOM in the water can react naturally with microorganisms, which in turn dissolve the iron- and arsenic-bearing minerals and release arsenic into solution. However, the relationship between arsenic and total DOM is not always consistent, and recent evidence suggests that DOM may undergo reactions with iron and arsenic that further promote high arsenic concentrations in groundwater. Gaps in our mechanistic understanding of the interactions between arsenic, iron, reactive organic carbon (DOM) and microbes continues to limit our ability to predict the distribution of arsenic in reducing aquifers.

The research conducted for this NSF project evaluated two arsenic afflicted aquifers, the Mahomet Aquifer in Illinois, USA and the West Bengal Aquifer in India to evaluate if processes occurring in the Mahomet are generalizable to other aquifers. Future research may deploy a unique deep aquifer sampling technology to collect uncompromised pore-water samples from the Mahomet Aquifer field site. Our results indicate that in terms of hydrology, the Mahomet Aquifer is flushed faster than aquifers in the Bengal Basin; the groundwater velocity in the Mahomet Aquifer was found to be approximately five times faster than in the West Bengal Aquifer. A reactive transport model further showed that the high velocities transport iron and other inorganic compounds, such as arsenic, ten times as far in the Mahomet Aquifer (Figure 2). 

In terms of the chemical character of DOM, groundwater samples collected from both aquifers contained DOM with qualities associated mainly with humic organic material derived from the dispersed organic sediments found in both aquifers. Experiments conducted with this humic DOM fraction, isolated from large volumes of Bengal Basin groundwater, revealed that humic DOM is able to greatly accelerate the process of iron and arsenic release from sediments. This finding means that sediments release organic compounds, possibly from deposition of plant material over the millennia, that have an innate ability to increase the concentration of iron and arsenic dissolving into groundwater. Although organic compounds derived from ponds and rivers may also reach the subsurface, this finding implicates organic matter in the sediments as a critical ingredient needed to maintain arsenic in solution. Indeed, the majority of of groundwater samples with low humic DOM content did not have high arsenic concentrations. Therefore, the presence of dispersed humic DOM in sediments may help to explain the patchy occurrence of arsenic, especially in reducing aquifers in the Bengal Basin.
